topic_name: Dual Nature of Radiation and Matter

canonical_explanation.text: The photoelectric effect is the emission of electrons from a metal surface when light of sufficiently high frequency falls on it. Key observations include: (i) emission is instantaneous, (ii) there exists a threshold frequency below which no emission occurs regardless of intensity, (iii) the maximum kinetic energy of emitted electrons depends on frequency but not on intensity, and (iv) the photoelectric current is proportional to the intensity of incident light. Einstein explained these observations by proposing that light consists of discrete quanta called photons, each carrying energy E = hf. His photoelectric equation is: K_max = hf - phi, where phi = hf_0 is the work function and f_0 is the threshold frequency. The stopping potential V_0 satisfies eV_0 = K_max. A photon of frequency f has energy E = hf, momentum p = hf/c = h/lambda, and zero rest mass. De Broglie proposed that matter also exhibits wave-like behaviour with wavelength lambda = h/p = h/(mv). For an electron accelerated through potential V, lambda = h/sqrt(2meV) = 1.227/sqrt(V) nm. The Davisson-Germer experiment confirmed the wave nature of electrons by observing diffraction of electrons from a nickel crystal.
rules: Photoelectric effect: emission is instantaneous; threshold frequency exists below which no emission occurs
Einstein's photoelectric equation: K_max = hf - phi, where phi is the work function
Stopping potential: eV_0 = K_max = hf - phi
Photon energy E = hf = hc/lambda; photon momentum p = h/lambda = E/c
Photoelectric current is proportional to intensity; K_max is independent of intensity
de Broglie wavelength: lambda = h/p = h/(mv)
For electron accelerated through V volts: lambda = 1.227/sqrt(V) nm
Davisson-Germer experiment confirmed wave nature of electrons via electron diffraction from nickel crystal

questions.question_text: In the photoelectric effect, the maximum kinetic energy of emitted photoelectrons depends on:
questions.explanation_correct: The maximum kinetic energy of photoelectrons depends only on the frequency of incident light and the work function of the metal, as given by K_max = hf - phi. It is independent of the intensity of light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Intensity affects the number of photoelectrons emitted (photoelectric current), not their maximum kinetic energy. The area of the surface and duration of illumination also do not affect K_max. Only the frequency of incident light determines the maximum kinetic energy.

questions.question_text: The photoelectric effect supports the:
questions.explanation_correct: The photoelectric effect cannot be explained by the wave theory of light. Einstein's explanation using the quantum (particle) theory of light, where light consists of photons each with energy hf, successfully explains all observed features of the photoelectric effect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wave theory predicts that emission should occur at any frequency if intensity is sufficient and that energy should build up gradually, both contradicting experimental observations. The photoelectric effect is direct evidence for the particle nature of light.

questions.question_text: The threshold frequency in the photoelectric effect is the:

options.text: Frequency at which photoelectric current becomes maximum
Minimum frequency below which no photoelectric emission occurs
Frequency at which stopping potential becomes zero

questions.explanation_correct: The threshold frequency f_0 is the minimum frequency of incident light below which no photoelectric emission occurs. At f = f_0, K_max = hf_0 - phi = 0, so the stopping potential V_0 is also zero. Both statements B and C are correct descriptions of the threshold frequency.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The threshold frequency is not about maximum current. It is the minimum frequency needed for emission. At this frequency, K_max = 0 and hence the stopping potential is also zero. Both B and C are correct, so D is the answer.

questions.question_text: When the intensity of incident light on a photosensitive surface is doubled (keeping frequency constant above threshold), the:

options.text: Maximum kinetic energy of photoelectrons is doubled
Number of photoelectrons emitted per second is doubled
Work function of the metal is halved

questions.explanation_correct: Doubling the intensity doubles the number of photons incident per second, which doubles the number of photoelectrons emitted per second (doubling the photoelectric current). The maximum kinetic energy and stopping potential remain unchanged as they depend only on frequency.
questions.explanation_incorrect: K_max and stopping potential depend only on frequency, not intensity, so they do not change. The work function is a property of the metal and does not change with incident light. Only the photoelectric current (number of electrons emitted per second) is proportional to intensity.

questions.question_text: In a photoelectric experiment, the graph of stopping potential V_0 versus frequency f of incident light is a straight line. The slope of this line is:
questions.explanation_correct: From Einstein's equation: eV_0 = hf - phi, so V_0 = (h/e)f - phi/e. This is a linear equation in f with slope h/e and y-intercept -phi/e. Hence the slope of the V_0 vs f graph is h/e.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The slope is not h alone because the equation V_0 = (h/e)f - phi/e shows the slope is h/e. The intercept on the V_0 axis is -phi/e, not the slope. The ratio e/h is the reciprocal of the actual slope.

questions.question_text: The work function of a metal is 2.0 eV. What is the maximum wavelength of light that can cause photoelectric emission from this metal? (h = 6.63 x 10^-34 J s, c = 3 x 10^8 m/s, 1 eV = 1.6 x 10^-19 J)
questions.explanation_correct: The maximum wavelength corresponds to the threshold frequency: lambda_max = hc/phi = (6.63 x 10^-34 x 3 x 10^8) / (2.0 x 1.6 x 10^-19) = 1.989 x 10^-25 / 3.2 x 10^-19 = 6.22 x 10^-7 m = 621 nm (approximately).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The maximum wavelength is found using lambda_max = hc/phi. Converting phi = 2.0 eV to joules gives 3.2 x 10^-19 J. Substituting: lambda_max = (6.63 x 10^-34)(3 x 10^8) / (3.2 x 10^-19) = 621 nm. Shorter wavelengths correspond to higher energies, which would also cause emission but are not the maximum wavelength.

questions.question_text: Light of frequency 1.5 times the threshold frequency is incident on a photosensitive material. If the frequency is halved and the intensity is doubled, what happens to the photoelectric current?
questions.explanation_correct: The original frequency is 1.5f_0. When halved, the new frequency is 0.75f_0, which is below the threshold frequency f_0. Below the threshold frequency, no photoelectric emission occurs regardless of intensity. Hence the photoelectric current becomes zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Even though intensity is doubled, since the new frequency (0.75f_0) is below the threshold frequency, no photoelectrons are emitted. The photoelectric effect requires the frequency to be above the threshold. Intensity only affects the number of electrons emitted when the frequency is above the threshold.

questions.question_text: In a photoelectric experiment with two metals A and B, metal A has a higher work function than metal B. If the same light of frequency f (above both threshold frequencies) illuminates both metals, then:

options.text: Metal A emits electrons with greater K_max
Metal B emits electrons with greater K_max
Both metals emit electrons with the same K_max
The stopping potential is the same for both

questions.explanation_correct: K_max = hf - phi. Since the same frequency f is used for both, the metal with lower work function (metal B) will have higher maximum kinetic energy. K_max(B) = hf - phi_B > K_max(A) = hf - phi_A because phi_B < phi_A.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since K_max = hf - phi, a higher work function means less kinetic energy is available for the emitted electrons. Metal A, with higher work function, gives lower K_max, not higher. The stopping potentials will also differ since V_0 = K_max/e.

questions.question_text: Einstein's photoelectric equation is:
questions.explanation_correct: Einstein's photoelectric equation states K_max = hf - phi, where hf is the energy of the incident photon and phi is the work function of the metal. The maximum kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectron equals the photon energy minus the minimum energy required to free the electron.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct equation is K_max = hf - phi, not hf + phi or phi - hf. The photon energy hf must exceed the work function phi for emission to occur, and the excess energy appears as kinetic energy of the emitted electron.

questions.question_text: The stopping potential in a photoelectric experiment is the:

options.text: Minimum positive potential needed to start emission
Maximum negative potential at which current becomes zero
Minimum negative (retarding) potential at which photoelectric current becomes zero
Potential at which current is maximum

questions.explanation_correct: The stopping potential V_0 is the minimum retarding (negative) potential applied to the collector that is just sufficient to stop the most energetic photoelectrons, reducing the photoelectric current to zero. It satisfies eV_0 = K_max.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The stopping potential is not about starting emission or maximising current. It is the minimum retarding potential that completely stops the photoelectric current by repelling even the most energetic photoelectrons back to the emitter.

questions.question_text: The work function of a metal in Einstein's photoelectric equation represents:

options.text: The total energy of incident photon
The maximum kinetic energy of emitted electrons
The minimum energy needed to remove an electron from the metal surface
The energy of the most tightly bound electron

questions.explanation_correct: The work function (phi) is the minimum energy required to liberate an electron from the surface of the metal. It is characteristic of the metal and equals hf_0, where f_0 is the threshold frequency.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The work function is not the photon energy or the K_max. It is the minimum binding energy of the most loosely bound surface electrons (not the most tightly bound). It represents the energy barrier that must be overcome for an electron to escape the metal surface.

questions.question_text: The work function of a metal is 4.2 eV. What is the stopping potential when light of energy 6.0 eV falls on it?
questions.explanation_correct: Using Einstein's equation: K_max = hf - phi = 6.0 - 4.2 = 1.8 eV. The stopping potential V_0 = K_max / e = 1.8 eV / e = 1.8 V.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The stopping potential is not equal to the work function or the photon energy. It equals K_max/e, where K_max = hf - phi = 6.0 - 4.2 = 1.8 eV. Since K_max is in eV and we divide by e, V_0 = 1.8 V.

questions.question_text: In a photoelectric experiment, the stopping potential for light of wavelength 400 nm is 1.1 V. What is the stopping potential for light of wavelength 300 nm? (hc = 1240 eV nm)
questions.explanation_incorrect: First find the work function using the 400 nm data: phi = hc/lambda_1 - eV_01 = 3.1 - 1.1 = 2.0 eV. Then use this to find V_02 = (hc/lambda_2 - phi)/e = (4.133 - 2.0) = 2.14 V. The stopping potential is not simply proportional to wavelength.

questions.question_text: In the V_0 versus frequency graph for the photoelectric effect, the intercept on the negative V_0 axis gives:

options.text: The work function divided by e (i.e., phi/e)

questions.explanation_correct: From V_0 = (h/e)f - phi/e, when f = 0, V_0 = -phi/e. The magnitude of the intercept on the negative V_0 axis is phi/e, which gives the work function in electron-volts when multiplied by e.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The slope of the line gives h/e, and the intercept on the frequency axis (V_0 = 0) gives the threshold frequency f_0. The intercept on the V_0 axis (f = 0) gives -phi/e. These are distinct quantities obtained from different features of the graph.

questions.question_text: Two metals X and Y have work functions 2.0 eV and 4.0 eV respectively. In a photoelectric experiment using the same light source, the ratio of their stopping potentials V_X : V_Y = 3 : 1. The energy of the photons emitted by the source is:
questions.explanation_correct: Let the photon energy be E. For metal X: eV_X = E - 2.0, so V_X = E - 2.0. For metal Y: eV_Y = E - 4.0, so V_Y = E - 4.0. Given V_X/V_Y = 3/1: (E - 2.0)/(E - 4.0) = 3. Solving: E - 2.0 = 3E - 12.0, so 2E = 10.0, E = 5.0 eV.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We must set up two equations from Einstein's photoelectric equation and use the ratio condition. V_X = (E - 2)/e and V_Y = (E - 4)/e. The ratio 3:1 gives (E-2)/(E-4) = 3, leading to E = 5.0 eV.

questions.question_text: A photosensitive metal has threshold wavelength 660 nm. When illuminated with light of wavelength 330 nm, the maximum velocity of photoelectrons is v. If the wavelength is changed to 220 nm, the maximum velocity will be: (Assume the same metal.)
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since K_max is proportional to v^2, we need to compare the kinetic energies. At 330 nm: K1 = hc/660. At 220 nm: K2 = 2hc/660 = 2K1. Since K is proportional to v^2, v' = sqrt(2)v.

questions.question_text: The momentum of a photon of wavelength lambda is:
questions.explanation_correct: The momentum of a photon is p = E/c = hf/c = h/lambda. This follows from the relation E = pc for massless particles and E = hf, combined with c = f lambda.
questions.explanation_incorrect: hc/lambda gives the energy of the photon, not its momentum. The momentum is p = h/lambda (not h*lambda). For a photon, p = E/c, and since E = hc/lambda, p = h/lambda.

questions.question_text: The rest mass of a photon is:

options.text: Equal to the mass of an electron

questions.explanation_correct: A photon is a massless particle; its rest mass is zero. It always travels at the speed of light c. The quantity hf/c^2 is sometimes called the equivalent or effective mass of the photon but is not its rest mass.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Photons have zero rest mass. They cannot be at rest and always move at the speed of light. The quantity hf/c^2 is the relativistic mass equivalent, not the rest mass. A photon's energy-momentum relation is E = pc, which holds only for massless particles.

questions.question_text: If the energy of a photon is doubled, its momentum:
questions.explanation_correct: For a photon, E = pc, so p = E/c. If energy is doubled, momentum is also doubled since they are directly proportional. Equivalently, p = h/lambda, and doubling E means halving lambda, which doubles p.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The momentum of a photon is directly proportional to its energy: p = E/c. When the energy doubles, the momentum doubles as well. It does not remain unchanged, get halved, or quadruple.

questions.question_text: The ratio of the energies of two photons of wavelengths 2000 angstrom and 4000 angstrom respectively is:
questions.explanation_correct: E = hc/lambda. For two photons, E_1/E_2 = lambda_2/lambda_1 = 4000/2000 = 2/1. The photon with shorter wavelength (2000 angstrom) has twice the energy of the one with longer wavelength (4000 angstrom).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since E is inversely proportional to lambda, the ratio of energies is the inverse ratio of wavelengths: E_1/E_2 = lambda_2/lambda_1 = 4000/2000 = 2:1. It is not a square relationship.

questions.question_text: A photon and an electron have the same energy E. The ratio of the wavelength of the photon to the de Broglie wavelength of the electron is proportional to:
questions.explanation_correct: Photon wavelength: lambda_ph = hc/E, so lambda_ph is proportional to 1/E. Electron de Broglie wavelength: lambda_e = h/sqrt(2mE), so lambda_e is proportional to 1/sqrt(E). Ratio: lambda_ph/lambda_e is proportional to (1/E)/(1/sqrt(E)) = 1/sqrt(E) = E^(-1/2).
questions.explanation_incorrect: For the photon, lambda = hc/E (inversely proportional to E). For the electron, lambda = h/sqrt(2mE) (inversely proportional to sqrt(E)). Their ratio is proportional to sqrt(E)/E = 1/sqrt(E) = E^(-1/2).

questions.question_text: A photon of wavelength 0.1 nm has momentum (h = 6.63 x 10^-34 J s):
questions.explanation_incorrect: The momentum of a photon is p = h/lambda. Converting 0.1 nm = 10^-10 m: p = 6.63 x 10^-34 / 10^-10 = 6.63 x 10^-24 kg m/s. Be careful with unit conversions: 1 nm = 10^-9 m.

questions.question_text: A photon and an electron have the same de Broglie wavelength lambda. If p_ph and p_e are their momenta, and E_ph and E_e are their energies, then:

options.text: p_ph = p_e but E_ph is not equal to E_e
p_ph is not equal to p_e but E_ph = E_e
p_ph is not equal to p_e and E_ph is not equal to E_e

questions.explanation_correct: Both photon and electron have the same wavelength lambda, so both have the same momentum p = h/lambda. However, their energies differ: for the photon, E_ph = pc, and for the electron, E_e = p^2/(2m). Since pc >> p^2/(2m) for typical wavelengths, E_ph >> E_e. Equal wavelength means equal momentum, but not equal energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same wavelength implies same momentum (p = h/lambda), but the energy-momentum relationships differ: E = pc for photon and E = p^2/(2m) for electron. So momenta are equal but energies are not.

questions.question_text: The number of photons of wavelength 660 nm emitted per second by a 60 W source is approximately: (h = 6.6 x 10^-34 J s, c = 3 x 10^8 m/s)
questions.explanation_correct: Energy of one photon: E = hc/lambda = (6.6 x 10^-34 x 3 x 10^8) / (660 x 10^-9) = 1.98 x 10^-25 / 6.6 x 10^-7 = 3 x 10^-19 J. Number of photons per second: n = P/E = 60 / (3 x 10^-19) = 2 x 10^20.
questions.explanation_incorrect: First calculate the energy per photon: E = hc/lambda = 3 x 10^-19 J. Then n = Power/E = 60/(3 x 10^-19) = 2 x 10^20 photons per second. Power equals the number of photons per second times the energy per photon.

questions.question_text: The de Broglie wavelength associated with a moving particle is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: De Broglie proposed that every moving particle has a wave associated with it, with wavelength lambda = h/p, where h is Planck's constant and p is the momentum of the particle. This is known as the de Broglie relation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The de Broglie wavelength is lambda = h/p, not hp, p/h, or h^2/p. It shows that the wavelength is inversely proportional to the momentum: faster or heavier particles have shorter wavelengths.

questions.question_text: The de Broglie wavelength of an electron accelerated through a potential difference V is:
questions.explanation_correct: An electron accelerated through potential V gains kinetic energy eV. So (1/2)mv^2 = eV, giving p = mv = sqrt(2meV). The de Broglie wavelength is lambda = h/p = h/sqrt(2meV). Numerically, lambda = 1.227/sqrt(V) nm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The kinetic energy gained is eV, and p = sqrt(2mK) = sqrt(2meV). The de Broglie wavelength is lambda = h/p = h/sqrt(2meV). The other options have incorrect algebraic forms.

questions.question_text: The Davisson-Germer experiment confirmed the:
questions.explanation_correct: The Davisson-Germer experiment demonstrated the diffraction of electrons by a nickel crystal, confirming de Broglie's hypothesis that electrons (and matter in general) exhibit wave-like behaviour. The measured wavelength matched de Broglie's prediction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The experiment used electrons (not light) and observed their diffraction by a crystal. This confirmed the wave nature of electrons, supporting de Broglie's hypothesis. The nuclear model was established by Rutherford's alpha-scattering experiment.

questions.question_text: The de Broglie wavelength of a particle is significant (observable) only when the particle is:
questions.explanation_correct: The de Broglie wavelength is lambda = h/mv. Since h is extremely small (6.63 x 10^-34 J s), for macroscopic objects with large mass and momentum, the wavelength is undetectably small. Only for microscopic particles like electrons, protons, and neutrons is the wavelength comparable to atomic dimensions and thus observable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For macroscopic objects, the mass is so large that lambda = h/mv becomes negligibly small, making wave effects unobservable. The wave nature is significant only for particles of atomic or subatomic dimensions. Charge is not the relevant factor.

questions.question_text: An electron and a proton are accelerated through the same potential difference. The ratio of their de Broglie wavelengths (lambda_e / lambda_p) is:
questions.explanation_correct: lambda = h/sqrt(2mqV), where q and V are the same for both (same charge e, same potential V). So lambda_e/lambda_p = sqrt(m_p / m_e). Since m_p >> m_e, the electron has a much larger de Broglie wavelength.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since lambda = h/sqrt(2meV) and both have the same charge and same V, the ratio depends only on the masses: lambda_e/lambda_p = sqrt(m_p/m_e). The wavelength is inversely proportional to the square root of mass.

questions.question_text: If the kinetic energy of a particle is doubled, its de Broglie wavelength becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: lambda = h/p = h/sqrt(2mK). If K is doubled, lambda' = h/sqrt(2m(2K)) = h/(sqrt(2) x sqrt(2mK)) = lambda/sqrt(2). So the wavelength becomes 1/sqrt(2) times the original.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since lambda is inversely proportional to sqrt(K), doubling K gives lambda' = lambda/sqrt(2) = lambda x (1/sqrt(2)). The wavelength decreases but not by half; it decreases by a factor of sqrt(2).

questions.question_text: The de Broglie wavelength of an electron accelerated through 100 V is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: Using the formula lambda = 1.227/sqrt(V) nm = 1.227/sqrt(100) = 1.227/10 = 0.1227 nm, approximately 0.123 nm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formula lambda = 1.227/sqrt(V) nm gives: lambda = 1.227/10 = 0.1227 nm for V = 100 V. Be careful with the formula: sqrt(100) = 10, not 100 or 1.

questions.question_text: An alpha particle, a proton, an electron, and a neutron all have the same kinetic energy. Which has the longest de Broglie wavelength?
questions.explanation_correct: lambda = h/sqrt(2mK). For the same kinetic energy K, the particle with the smallest mass has the longest wavelength. The electron has the smallest mass among the four, so it has the longest de Broglie wavelength.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since lambda = h/sqrt(2mK) and K is the same for all, lambda is inversely proportional to sqrt(m). The lightest particle (electron) has the longest wavelength. The alpha particle, being the heaviest, has the shortest wavelength.

questions.question_text: In the Davisson-Germer experiment, the peak in the electron diffraction pattern was observed at a scattering angle of 50 degrees for an accelerating voltage of 54 V. This experiment used:

options.text: Electrons scattered from a gold foil
Electrons diffracted from a nickel crystal

questions.explanation_correct: In the Davisson-Germer experiment, a beam of electrons accelerated through 54 V was directed at a nickel crystal. A peak in the scattered electron intensity was observed at 50 degrees, corresponding to a wavelength that matched the de Broglie prediction of 0.167 nm, confirming electron diffraction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Davisson-Germer experiment specifically used electrons (not protons or X-rays) and a nickel crystal (not gold foil). Gold foil was used in Rutherford's alpha-scattering experiment, which is a different experiment proving the nuclear model of the atom.

questions.question_text: A particle of mass m is moving with velocity v. Its de Broglie wavelength is lambda. If it is brought to rest by a retarding potential and then accelerated through a potential that gives it a de Broglie wavelength of lambda/2, its new kinetic energy is:
questions.explanation_correct: lambda = h/sqrt(2mK), so K = h^2/(2m lambda^2). If lambda' = lambda/2, then K' = h^2/(2m (lambda/2)^2) = h^2/(2m lambda^2/4) = 4 x h^2/(2m lambda^2) = 4K. The new kinetic energy is 4 times the original.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since K is proportional to 1/lambda^2, halving the wavelength increases the kinetic energy by a factor of (1/(1/2))^2 = 4. The relationship between kinetic energy and wavelength is K proportional to 1/lambda^2.

questions.question_text: Radiation of wavelength lambda is incident on a metal surface. If the maximum kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectrons is 3.2 x 10^-19 J and the stopping potential is 2 V, the work function of the metal is: (Given: hc = 1240 eV nm, 1 eV = 1.6 x 10^-19 J)

options.text: Cannot be determined without knowing lambda

questions.explanation_correct: We know K_max = 3.2 x 10^-19 J = 2 eV, and eV_0 = K_max gives V_0 = 2 V (consistent). But to find the work function, we need phi = hf - K_max = hc/lambda - 2 eV, which requires knowing lambda. The two given pieces of information (K_max and V_0) are not independent; they give the same information. We need the wavelength to determine the work function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: K_max = eV_0, so 3.2 x 10^-19 J = e x 2 V = 3.2 x 10^-19 J. These are the same piece of information stated two ways. Without knowing the wavelength or frequency of the incident light, we cannot determine the work function using phi = hf - K_max.

questions.question_text: The photoelectric emission from a metal surface starts instantaneously (within 10^-9 s) when light of appropriate frequency falls on it. This observation:

options.text: Can be explained by the wave theory of light
Cannot be explained by the wave theory but can be explained by the quantum theory
Can be explained by both wave and quantum theories
Cannot be explained by either theory

questions.explanation_correct: The wave theory predicts that energy is absorbed continuously and gradually by the electron, requiring a considerable time delay (hours for low intensity) before emission. The quantum theory explains instantaneous emission since a single photon delivers its entire energy to a single electron in one event.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wave theory cannot explain the instantaneous nature of the photoelectric effect. According to wave theory, energy should accumulate gradually, leading to a time lag. The quantum theory explains this by treating light as discrete photons that transfer energy in a single interaction.

questions.question_text: The graph of K_max versus frequency for the photoelectric effect is a straight line. The x-intercept of this line gives:
questions.explanation_correct: From K_max = hf - phi, when K_max = 0, hf = phi, so f = phi/h = f_0 (the threshold frequency). The x-intercept of the K_max vs f graph is the threshold frequency f_0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The slope of the K_max vs f line gives Planck's constant h. The x-intercept (where K_max = 0) gives the threshold frequency f_0. The y-intercept gives -phi. The stopping potential is found from V_0 = K_max/e.

questions.question_text: A proton and an alpha particle have the same de Broglie wavelength. The ratio of their velocities (v_proton / v_alpha) is:
questions.explanation_correct: lambda = h/(mv). If lambda_p = lambda_alpha, then m_p v_p = m_alpha v_alpha. So v_p/v_alpha = m_alpha/m_p = 4m_p/m_p = 4. The ratio v_p : v_alpha = 4 : 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same wavelength means same momentum: m_p v_p = m_alpha v_alpha. Since m_alpha = 4m_p, we get v_p = 4v_alpha, giving the ratio 4:1. The proton must move 4 times faster to have the same wavelength as the heavier alpha particle.

questions.question_text: The saturation photoelectric current depends on:

options.text: Both frequency and intensity of incident light

questions.explanation_correct: Saturation current depends on the number of photoelectrons emitted per second, which is proportional to the intensity (number of photons per second). However, the frequency must be above the threshold for any emission to occur. Thus, both frequency (must exceed f_0) and intensity (determines current magnitude) affect the saturation current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While the saturation current is directly proportional to intensity (for a fixed frequency above threshold), the frequency still plays a role: if the frequency is below the threshold, no current flows regardless of intensity. Both factors must be considered.

questions.question_text: The stopping potential for photoelectrons emitted from a surface illuminated by light of wavelength 491 nm is 0.71 V. The stopping potential when the same surface is illuminated by light of wavelength 405 nm is: (hc = 1240 eV nm)
questions.explanation_correct: For 491 nm: phi = hc/491 - 0.71 = 2.526 - 0.71 = 1.816 eV. For 405 nm: V_0 = hc/405 - phi = 3.062 - 1.816 = 1.246 V, approximately 1.22 V (rounding of hc/491 = 2.526 gives phi approximately 1.82 eV, and 3.062 - 1.82 = 1.24 V, approximately 1.22 V).
questions.explanation_incorrect: First find phi from the 491 nm data: phi = 1240/491 - 0.71 = 2.53 - 0.71 = 1.82 eV. Then V_0 for 405 nm = 1240/405 - 1.82 = 3.06 - 1.82 = 1.24 V, closest to 1.22 V.

questions.question_text: A photon of energy 2 MeV has a momentum of approximately: (c = 3 x 10^8 m/s, 1 MeV = 1.6 x 10^-13 J)
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a photon, p = E/c. Converting 2 MeV to joules: E = 2 x 1.6 x 10^-13 = 3.2 x 10^-13 J. Then p = 3.2 x 10^-13 / 3 x 10^8 = 1.07 x 10^-21 kg m/s.

questions.question_text: In the Davisson-Germer experiment, the crystal used was:
questions.explanation_correct: Davisson and Germer used a nickel crystal as the target in their electron diffraction experiment. The regular arrangement of nickel atoms in the crystal acted as a diffraction grating for the electron waves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Davisson-Germer experiment specifically used a nickel crystal. Gold foil was used in Rutherford's experiment. Silver and copper were not used in the original Davisson-Germer experiment.

questions.question_text: The energy of a photon of wavelength lambda is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: The energy of a photon is E = hf. Since c = f lambda, f = c/lambda, and therefore E = hc/lambda. This shows that photon energy is inversely proportional to wavelength.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The energy is E = hf = hc/lambda, where h is Planck's constant, c is the speed of light, and lambda is the wavelength. It is inversely proportional to wavelength, not directly proportional.

questions.question_text: Ultraviolet light of wavelength 200 nm can cause photoelectric emission from a metal, but visible light of wavelength 500 nm cannot. The work function of the metal lies between:
questions.explanation_correct: Energy of 500 nm photon: E_1 = 1240/500 = 2.48 eV. Energy of 200 nm photon: E_2 = 1240/200 = 6.20 eV. Since 500 nm cannot cause emission, phi > 2.48 eV. Since 200 nm can cause emission, phi < 6.20 eV. So phi lies between 2.48 eV and 6.20 eV.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The work function must be above the energy of 500 nm photons (2.48 eV, since these cannot cause emission) and below the energy of 200 nm photons (6.20 eV, since these do cause emission). This gives 2.48 eV < phi < 6.20 eV.

questions.question_text: In Einstein's photoelectric equation K_max = hf - phi, the symbol h represents:
questions.explanation_correct: In Einstein's photoelectric equation, h is Planck's constant with value 6.63 x 10^-34 J s. It is a fundamental constant of nature that relates the energy of a photon to its frequency: E = hf.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The symbol h is Planck's constant, not the work function (phi), threshold frequency (f_0), or kinetic energy (K_max). It is a universal constant with value 6.63 x 10^-34 J s.

questions.question_text: The de Broglie wavelength of an electron (mass 9.1 x 10^-31 kg) moving with a velocity of 10^6 m/s is approximately: (h = 6.6 x 10^-34 J s)
questions.explanation_incorrect: lambda = h/(mv) = 6.6 x 10^-34 / (9.1 x 10^-31 x 10^6). Calculating the denominator: 9.1 x 10^-25. Then lambda = 6.6/9.1 x 10^-9 = 0.725 nm, approximately 0.73 nm.

questions.question_text: When a photon of energy hf strikes a free electron at rest and is completely absorbed, the kinetic energy acquired by the electron is:

options.text: A free electron cannot completely absorb a photon

questions.explanation_correct: A free electron cannot completely absorb a photon because simultaneous conservation of energy and momentum is impossible in such a process. Complete absorption of a photon by a free electron would violate the conservation laws. This is why the photoelectric effect requires bound electrons in a metal (the metal lattice absorbs the recoil momentum).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Complete absorption of a photon by a free electron at rest is not possible. If we assume energy conservation gives the electron KE = hf, the momentum conservation cannot be simultaneously satisfied. A bound electron in a metal can absorb a photon because the lattice absorbs the recoil momentum.

questions.question_text: The de Broglie wavelengths of an electron and a proton are equal. The ratio of their kinetic energies (K_e / K_p) is:
questions.explanation_correct: K = p^2/(2m) and p = h/lambda. If lambda_e = lambda_p, then p_e = p_p. So K_e/K_p = (p^2/(2m_e))/(p^2/(2m_p)) = m_p/m_e. The electron, being much lighter, has much higher kinetic energy for the same wavelength (same momentum).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal wavelength means equal momentum. Since K = p^2/(2m), for equal momentum, K_e/K_p = m_p/m_e. The lighter particle (electron) has greater kinetic energy.

questions.question_text: Monochromatic light of frequency 6 x 10^14 Hz is produced by a laser. Each photon has energy: (h = 6.63 x 10^-34 J s)
questions.explanation_incorrect: E = hf = 6.63 x 10^-34 x 6 x 10^14 = 3.978 x 10^-19 J. Simply multiply Planck's constant by the frequency to get the energy of one photon.

questions.question_text: The photoelectric effect was first experimentally observed by:
questions.explanation_correct: The photoelectric effect was first observed by Heinrich Hertz in 1887 during his experiments on electromagnetic waves. He noticed that ultraviolet light facilitated the production of sparks. Einstein later explained the effect theoretically in 1905 using the photon concept.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Einstein explained the photoelectric effect theoretically in 1905 (for which he won the Nobel Prize), but the effect was first experimentally observed by Heinrich Hertz in 1887. Planck introduced the quantum hypothesis for blackbody radiation, and de Broglie proposed the wave nature of matter.
